newsitem.title: USA: Oscar protests range from sex, God to Mickey.
newsitem.headline: Oscar protests range from sex, God to Mickey.

text.p: The Academy Awards show, never a stranger to controversy, became a magnet on Monday for issues ranging from sex to Mickey Mouse.
As limousines began to arrive at the Shrine Auditorium for the 69th Academy Awards, protesters were on the streets that were lined with fans hoping for a glimpse of the stars.

One group held anti-Disney placards over allegations about using child labour to make merchandise and another crowd of free speech proponents displayed signs hailing Larry Flynt, the controversial publisher of Hustler magazine.
Among their slogans were "Hollywood Bent Over For Gloria, Censorship Is Free-Dumb," in reference to feminist Gloria Steinem, and "Flynt Is Our Hero."
Several fundamentalist Christians held up placards denouncing Flynt, whose tumultuous life is the subject of "The People vs. Larry Flynt," which earned two Oscar nominations.
This group's posters read "No Adultry. No Perverts."
Others slammed Hollywood in general with "Movie Scum Repent -- Stop Promoting Sin."

Another Christian group chanted "No to Larry Flynt" from the bleachers when the publisher arrived at the event. Flynt's arrival was somewhat of a surprise after he had bitterly complained recently that he was snubbed by Columbia Pictures for not inviting him.
Before the ceremonies, one airplane circling the Shrine Auditorium pulled a banner with the legend "Columbia Studios suck -- L. Flynt."
Flynt has been the subject of criticism by feminists, spearheaded by author Steinem who placed a full page notice in numerous trade papers.
Steinem claimed the film glorified the abuse of women while inaccurately painting Flynt as a crusader for free speech.

Flynt arrived in a stretch white limousine with a hand painted picture of a reclining nude emblazoned on the side. Wearing a sequined tuxedo, Flynt was escorted in a gold-plated wheelchair to the applause of his fans.

As the ceremonies began it did not take long for Flynt to get a mention. Joking about the special effects on the film "Twister," host Billy Crystal said "200 miles an hour, that's almost enough wind to blow Gloria Steinem to a screening of Larry Flynt."
When the crowd responded loudly, Crystal said "that sounded a bit like a Disney shareholders meeting for a while."

Last month Disney shareholders protested at the company's annual meeting claiming the entertainment giant used contractors that employed child labour sweatshops in Haiti to make clothing and other Disney merchandise.
Outside a plane pulled a banner that read "Disney uses sweatshops -- 30 cents an hour in Haiti."

The ceremony was largely devoid of any political controversy although President Bill Clinton's fund-raising methods were the brunt of some jocularity. Crystal joked that Clinton had made a film called "101 Donations."
